introduction.p: Frequently, when doing mathematics, we need to establish a universe or set of elements under discussion. For example, the set A = \{x : 81x^4 -16 = 0 \} contains different elements depending on what kinds of numbers we allow ourselves to use in solving the equation 81 x^4 -16 = 0. This set of numbers would be our universe. For example, if the universe is the integers, then A is empty. If our universe is the rational numbers, then A is \{2/3, -2/3\} and if the universe is the complex numbers, then A is \{2/3, -2/3, 2i/3, - 2i/3\}.

statement.p: The universe, or universal set, is the set of all elements under discussion for possible membership in a set. We normally reserve the letter U for a universe in general discussions.

introduction.p: Now that we have the basic concepts around sets, we can discuss how we can combine sets to make other sets. Just as there are many ways to combine two numbers to get a new number (e.g.addition or multiplication) there are a variety of ways in which we can combine two or more sets to get a new set.

subsection.title: The Algebra of Sets
subsection.p: Suppose we have two sets, A and B. We've already seen how to define the case when one set is completely contained within another set (subset), but what about the case when two sets have some elements in common, and some elements which only belong to one set or the other? This leads us to the definition of intersection:

notation.description: The intersection of A and B.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The intersection of A and B (denoted by A \cap B) is the set of all elements that are in both A and B. That is, A \cap B = \{x:x \in A \textrm{ and } x \in B\}.

ul.li: Solving a system of simultaneous equations such as x + y = 7 and x - y = 3 can be viewed as an intersection. Let A = \{(x,y): x + y = 7, x,y \in \mathbb{R}\} and B = \{(x,y): x - y = 3, x,y\in \mathbb{R}\}. These two sets are lines in the plane and their intersection, A \cap B = \{(5, 2)\}, is the solution to the system.

li.p: If A = \{3, 5, 9\} and B = \{-5, 8\}, then A\cap B =\emptyset.

subsection.p: When working with sets, as in other branches of mathematics, it is often quite useful to be able to draw a picture or diagram of the situation under consideration. A diagram of a set is called a Venn diagram. The universal set U is represented by the interior of a rectangle and the sets by disks inside the rectangle.
A \cap B is illustrated in by shading the appropriate region.

subsection.p: In a Venn diagram, the region representing A \cap B does not appear empty; however, in some instances it will represent the empty set. The same is true for any other region in a Venn diagram.
We can also create a new set that contains all the distinct elements from both sets. This new set is called the union:

notation.description: The union of A and B.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The union of A and B (denoted by A \cup B) is the set of all elements that are in A or in B or in both A and B. That is, A\cup B= \{x:x \in A\textrm{ or } x\in B\}.

subsection.p: It is important to note in the set-builder notation for A\cup B, the word or is used in the inclusive sense; it includes the case where x is in both A and B.

li.p: A \cup \emptyset = A for any set A.

subsection.p: Of course, it's possible to have two sets that have no elements in common. In this case, we say that the sets are disjoint:

statement.p: Two sets are disjoint if they have no elements in common. That is, A and B are disjoint if A \cap B = \emptyset.

subsection.p: We also need to have a way of talking about the elements that occur in one set, but not in some other set.

notation.description: The complement of A relative to B.
The complement of A relative to B.
The complement of A relative to the universe.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The complement of A relative to B (notation B - A or B\setminus A) is the set of elements that are in B and not in A. That is, B-A=\{x: x\in B \textrm{ and } x\notin A\}. If U is the universal set, then U-A is denoted by A^c and is called simply the complement of A. A^c=\{x\in U : x\notin A\}.

notation.description: The symmetric difference of A and B.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The symmetric difference of A and B (denoted by A\oplus B) is the set of all elements that are in A and B but not in both. That is, A \oplus B = (A \cup B) - (A \cap B).

ol.label: (a)
ol.li: A \oplus 0 = A and A \oplus A = \emptyset for any set A.
\mathbb{R} \oplus \mathbb{Q} is the set of irrational numbers.

subsection.title: Cartesian Products

notation.description: The cartesian product of A with B.

statement.p: Let A and B be sets. The Cartesian product of A and B, denoted by A\times B, is defined as follows: A\times B = \{(a, b) \mid a \in A \quad\textrm{and}\quad b \in B\}, that is, A\times B is the set of all possible ordered pairs whose first component comes from A and whose second component comes from B.

example.title: Some Cartesian Products
example.p: Notation in mathematics is often developed for good reason. In this case, a few examples will make clear why the symbol $\times $ is used for Cartesian products.

li.p: Let A = \{1, 2, 3\} and B = \{4, 5\}. Then A \times B = \{(1, 4), (1, 5), (2, 4), (2, 5), (3, 4), (3, 5)\}. Note that |A \times B| = 6 = \lvert A \rvert \times \lvert B \rvert .

subsection.p: These two examples illustrate the general rule that if \(A\) and \(B\) are finite sets, then \lvert A \times B \rvert = \lvert A \rvert \times \lvert B \rvert .
We can define the Cartesian product of three (or more) sets similarly. For example, A \times B \times C = \{(a, b, c):a \in A, b \in B, c \in C\}.

It is common to use exponents if the sets in a Cartesian product are the same: A^2= A \times A A^3=A \times A \times A and in general, A^n = \underset{n \textrm{ factors}}{\underline{A \times A \times \ldots \times A}}.
